iti40:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, ignorance precedes the attainment of unskillful qualities, with lack of conscience and prudence following along.

iti40:2.2.pli: vijjā ca kho, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā anvadeva hirottappan”ti.
iti40:2.2.eng: Knowledge precedes the attainment of skillful qualities, with conscience and prudence following along.”

iti41:2.1.pli: “Te, bhikkhave, sattā suparihīnā ye ariyāya paññāya parihīnā.
iti41:2.1.eng: “Those sentient beings are truly bereft, mendicants, who are bereft of noble wisdom.

iti41:2.2.pli: Te diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṃ viharanti savighātaṃ saupāyāsaṃ sapariḷāhaṃ;
iti41:2.2.eng: They live unhappily in this very life—with distress, anguish, and fever—

iti41:2.3.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā.
iti41:2.3.eng: and when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect a bad rebirth.

iti41:2.4.pli: Te, bhikkhave, sattā aparihīnā ye ariyāya paññāya aparihīnā.
iti41:2.4.eng: Those sentient beings are not bereft who are not bereft of noble wisdom.

iti41:2.5.pli: Te diṭṭheva dhamme sukhaṃ viharanti avighātaṃ anupāyāsaṃ apariḷāhaṃ;
iti41:2.5.eng: In this very life they’re happy—free of distress, anguish, and fever—

iti41:2.6.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugati pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
iti41:2.6.eng: and when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect a good rebirth.”

iti41:4.1.eng: Wisdom is best in the world,

iti41:4.4.eng: the ending of rebirth and continued existence.

iti42:2.1.eng: “These two bright things, mendicants, protect the world.

iti42:2.4.pli: Ime ce, bhikkhave, dve sukkā dhammā lokaṃ na pāleyyuṃ, nayidha paññāyetha mātāti vā mātucchāti vā mātulānīti vā ācariyabhariyāti vā garūnaṃ dārāti vā.
iti42:2.4.eng: If these two bright things did not protect the world, there would be no recognition of the status of mother, aunts, or wives and partners of tutors and respected people.

iti42:2.5.pli: Sambhedaṃ loko agamissa yathā ajeḷakā kukkuṭasūkarā soṇasiṅgālā.
iti42:2.5.eng: The world would become dissolute, like goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and hounds and jackals.

iti42:2.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, ime dve sukkā dhammā lokaṃ pālenti tasmā paññāyati mātāti vā mātucchāti vā mātulānīti vā ācariyabhariyāti vā garūnaṃ dārāti vā”ti.
iti42:2.6.eng: But because the two bright things protect the world, there is recognition of the status of mother, aunts, and wives and partners of tutors and respected people.”

iti42:3.4.eng: and fare on in birth and death.

iti42:4.4.eng: being at peace, they will not be reborn again.”

iti43:2.1.eng: “There is, mendicants, freedom from rebirth, freedom from what has been produced, made, and conditioned.

iti43:2.2.pli: No cetaṃ, bhikkhave, abhavissa ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ, nayidha jātassa bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyetha.
iti43:2.2.eng: If there were no freedom from rebirth, freedom from what has been produced, made, and conditioned, then you would find no escape here from rebirth, from what has been produced, made, and conditioned.

iti43:2.3.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ, tasmā jātassa bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyatī”ti.
iti43:2.3.eng: But since there is freedom from rebirth, freedom from what has been produced, made, and conditioned, an escape is found from rebirth, from what has been produced, made, and conditioned.”

iti43:3.3.eng: wrapped in old age and death,

iti43:4.1.eng: whose inception is the leash to food:

iti43:4.2.eng: that’s not fit to delight in.

iti44:2.1.eng: “There are, mendicants, these two elements of extinguishment.

iti44:2.3.pli: Saupādisesā ca nibbānadhātu, anupādisesā ca nibbānadhātu.
iti44:2.3.eng: The element of extinguishment with residue, and the element of extinguishment with no residue.

iti44:3.1.eng: And what is the element of extinguishment with residue?

iti44:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto.
iti44:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.

iti44:3.3.pli: Tassa tiṭṭhanteva pañcindriyāni yesaṃ avighātattā manāpāmanāpaṃ paccanubhoti, sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
iti44:3.3.eng: Their five sense faculties still remain. So long as their senses have not gone they continue to experience the agreeable and disagreeable, to feel pleasure and pain.

iti44:3.4.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion in them

iti44:3.5.eng: is called the element of extinguishment with residue.

iti44:4.1.eng: And what is the element of extinguishment with no residue?

iti44:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto.
iti44:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.

iti44:4.3.pli: Tassa idheva, bhikkhave, sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sīti bhavissanti.
iti44:4.3.eng: For them, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.

iti44:4.4.eng: This is called the element of extinguishment with no residue.

iti44:4.5.eng: These are the two elements of extinguishment.”

iti44:5.1.eng: “These two elements of extinguishment <j>have been explained

iti44:5.2.eng: by the Clear-eyed One, <j>the unattached, the unaffected.

iti44:5.3.eng: One element pertains to this life—

iti44:5.4.eng: that with residue though the leash to existence has ended;

iti44:5.5.eng: and that with no residue, <j>which pertains to what follows this life,

iti44:5.6.eng: where all states of existence cease.

iti44:6.1.eng: Those who have fully understood <j>the unconditioned state—

iti44:6.2.eng: their minds freed, the leash to existence ended—

iti44:6.3.eng: attained to the heart of the Dhamma, <j>they delight in ending,

iti44:6.4.eng: the unaffected ones have given up <j>all states of existence.”

iti45:2.1.pli: “Paṭisallānārāmā, bhikkhave, viharatha paṭisallānaratā, ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyuttā, anirākatajjhānā, vipassanāya samannāgatā, brūhetāro suññāgārānaṃ.
iti45:2.1.eng: “Enjoy retreat, mendicants, love retreat. Be committed to inner serenity of the heart, don’t neglect absorption, be endowed with discernment, and frequent empty huts.

iti45:2.2.pli: Paṭisallānārāmānaṃ, bhikkhave, viharataṃ paṭisallānaratānaṃ ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyuttānaṃ anirākatajjhānānaṃ vipassanāya samannāgatānaṃ brūhetānaṃ suññāgārānaṃ dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
iti45:2.2.eng: A mendicant who enjoys retreat can expect one of two results:

iti45:2.3.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
iti45:2.3.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

iti45:4.4.eng: and has drawn near to extinguishment.”

iti46:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, live with training as benefit, with wisdom as overseer, with freedom as core, and with mindfulness as ruler.

iti46:2.2.pli: Sikkhānisaṃsānaṃ, bhikkhave, viharataṃ paññuttarānaṃ vimuttisārānaṃ satādhipateyyānaṃ dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
iti46:2.2.eng: A mendicant who lives in this way can expect one of two results:

iti46:2.3.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
iti46:2.3.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

iti46:3.2.eng: overseen by wisdom, seer of rebirth’s end;

iti46:3.3.eng: that sage bears their final body;

iti46:3.4.eng: they have disposed of Māra, I declare, <j>and gone beyond old age.

iti46:4.1.eng: Therefore be always enjoying absorption, <j>immersed in samādhi,

iti46:4.3.eng: Having overcome Māra and his armies, mendicants,

iti47:2.1.pli: “Jāgaro cassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vihareyya sato sampajāno samāhito pamudito vippasanno ca tattha kālavipassī ca kusalesu dhammesu.
iti47:2.1.eng: “A mendicant should meditate wakeful, mendicants, mindful and aware, joyful and clear, and at times discern the skillful qualities in that state.

iti47:2.2.pli: Jāgarassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno viharato satassa sampajānassa samāhitassa pamuditassa vippasannassa tattha kālavipassino kusalesu dhammesu dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
iti47:2.2.eng: A mendicant who meditates in this way can expect one of two results:

iti47:2.3.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
iti47:2.3.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

iti47:3.4.eng: the wakeful have nothing to fear.

iti47:4.1.eng: Those who are wakeful, mindful and aware,

iti47:4.2.eng: immersed in samādhi, joyful and clear,

iti47:4.3.eng: rightly investigating the Dhamma in good time,

iti47:4.4.eng: at one, would banish the darkness.

iti47:5.1.eng: That’s why you should apply yourself to wakefulness.

iti47:5.2.eng: A keen and alert mendicant, possessing absorption,

iti47:5.3.eng: having cut the fetter of birth and old age,

iti47:5.4.eng: would experience supreme awakening <j>in this very life.”

iti48:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, these two are bound for a place of loss, bound for hell, if they don’t give up this fault.

iti48:2.3.pli: Yo ca abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño, yo ca paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carantaṃ amūlakena abrahmacariyena anuddhaṃseti.
iti48:2.3.eng: Someone who is unchaste, but claims to be chaste; and someone who makes a groundless accusation of unchastity against a person whose chastity is pure.

iti48:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve āpāyikā nerayikā idamappahāyā”ti.
iti48:2.4.eng: These are the two who are bound for a place of loss, bound for hell, if they don’t give up this fault.”

iti48:3.2.pli: Yo vāpi katvā na karomi cāha;
iti48:3.2.eng: as does one who denies what they did.

iti48:3.3.eng: Both are equal in the hereafter,

iti48:4.1.eng: Many who wear a scrap of ocher cloth
iti48:4.1.comm: Kāsāvakaṇṭhā is usually taken as “ochre-necks” with kaṇṭha in the sense “throat”, but the commentary is not so clear: “It seems that, having tied a single ochre scrap (khaṇḍa) around their hand or neck (gīvā) they wander about.” Thus while the commentary mentions the neck, it directly glosses kaṇṭha with khaṇḍa, a term for a scrap or portion; eg. a cammakhaṇḍa is an item made from scraps of leather (Bu Pc 15:2.1.8). Khaṇḍa is doubly appropriate, since it is a common word for “broken” precepts.

iti48:4.3.eng: Being wicked, they are reborn in hell

iti48:5.1.eng: It’d be better for the immoral and unrestrained

iti48:5.4.eng: than to eat the nation’s alms.”

iti49:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti49:2.1.pli: “Dvīhi, bhikkhave, diṭṭhigatehi pariyuṭṭhitā devamanussā olīyanti eke, atidhāvanti eke; cakkhumanto ca passanti.
iti49:2.1.eng: “Overcome by two misconceptions, mendicants, some gods and humans get stuck, some overreach, while those with vision see.

iti49:3.1.eng: And how do some get stuck?

iti49:3.2.pli: Bhavārāmā, bhikkhave, devamanussā bhavaratā bhavasammuditā tesaṃ bhavanirodhāya dhamme desiyamāne cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
iti49:3.2.eng: Because of love, delight, and enjoyment of existence, when the Dhamma is being taught for the cessation of existence, the minds of some gods and humans do not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

iti49:3.3.eng: That is how some get stuck.

iti49:4.2.pli: Bhaveneva kho paneke aṭṭīyamānā harāyamānā jigucchamānā vibhavaṃ abhinandanti—
iti49:4.2.eng: Some, becoming horrified, repelled, and disgusted with existence, delight in nonexistence:

iti49:4.3.pli: yato kira, bho, ayaṃ attā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā ucchijjati vinassati na hoti paraṃ maraṇā;
iti49:4.3.eng: ‘When this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death:

iti49:4.4.pli: etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ etaṃ yāthāvanti.
iti49:4.4.eng: that is peaceful, that is sublime, that is how it is.’

iti49:5.1.eng: And how do those with vision see?

iti49:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant sees what has come to be as having come to be.

iti49:5.3.pli: bhūtaṃ bhūtato disvā bhūtassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
iti49:5.3.eng: Seeing this, they are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding what has come to be.

iti49:5.4.eng: That is how those with vision see.”

iti49:6.1.eng: “Those who see what has come to be <j>as having come to be,

iti49:6.2.eng: and see the transcendence of what has come to be,

iti49:6.3.eng: are freed in accord with the truth,

iti49:6.4.eng: with the ending of craving for continued existence.

iti49:7.1.eng: They completely understand what has come to be,

iti49:7.2.eng: rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state.

iti49:7.3.eng: When what has come to be ceases to be,

iti49:7.4.eng: a mendicant does not come back to future lives.”

iti49:8.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti49:8.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
